document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the subgenus Osmia (Diceratosmia), with descriptions of four new species (Hymenoptera, Megachilidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the subgenus Osmia (Diceratosmia), with descriptions of four new species (Hymenoptera, Megachilidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Osmia conjuncta
Cresson 1864 : 31
–32 [Holotype female: Philadelphia];
Medler & Lussenhop 1968 : 42
–43 [diagnosis of male].

Osmia cressonii
Dalla Torre 1896 : 392
[replacement name for
quadridentata Cresson
, nec
quadridentata Fonscolombe 1879
, which is a junior synonym of
Hoplitis ( Anthocopa ) jakovlevi (Radoskowski)
,
Zanden 1996 : 885
]

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Females of
O . conjuncta
can be distinguished from all other small (i.e., intertegular distance 1.5–2.5 mm ), blue
Diceratosmia
except
O . marilaunidii
by the combination of lack of modified facial and scopal hairs, shiny clypeus and frons, and the smoothly rounded mesepisternum between the anterior and lateral surfaces. Females of
O . conjuncta
can be distinguished from
O . marilaunidii
by the relatively straight carina between the second and fourth mandibular teeth in
O . conjuncta
(forming at most one-fourth of a circle) versus more strongly semicircular in
O . marilaunidii
(forming ca. one-half of a circle), as well as by the sculpturing of the anterior surface of T1 (dull in
O . conjuncta
, polished in
O . marilaunidii
).

Males of
O . conjuncta
can be distinguished from all other blue/green
Diceratosmia
except
O . marilaunidii
by the strongly concave apical margin of S3; the acutely pointed lateral projections of T6; and the long, slender medioapical hairs on S4 that are well separated from the hairs on the far lateral sides of S4.
Osmia conjuncta
and
O . marilaunidii
can be separated by the dull anterior surface of the scape and anterior surface of T 1 in
O . conjuncta
(shiny in
O . marilaunidii
), the relatively densely punctate metepisternum (sparsely punctate in
O . marilaunidii
) and the lack or reduction of impunctate lateral areas subapically on S4 (large lateral impunctate areas occur in
O . marilaunidii
).
Distribution. Eastern United States and adjacent Canada as far west as Kansas ( Fig. 15 ).

Floral Associations. Asteraceae :
Senecio anonymus , Taraxacum
; Brassicaceae :
Brassica
; Fabaceae :
Lupinus perennis , Trifolium repens
; Rosaceae :
Fragaria , Rosa , Rubus flagellaris
; Rubiaceae :
Hedyotis nigricans
; Salicaceae :
Salix .

Comments.
Osmia conjuncta
has been documented as nesting in snail shells ( Rau 1937 ) and is likely polyletic ( Hurd 1979 ).
